elements.content: By employing a pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid ligand, 3-(2′,5′-dicarboxylphenyl)­pyridine acid (H2dcpy), a three-dimensional In3+-based metal–organic framework, H3O­[In3(dcpy)4(OH)2]·3DMF·4H2O (1), with a good chemical stability toward acid and base has been synthesized. The compound 1 shows an uncommon (3,8)-connected tfz-d; UO3 topological net based on linear In3(COO)4(OH)2 clusters and also contains one-dimensional open channels. Particularly, 1 contains two types of dcpy2– linkers, in which the pyridyl group in one participates in coordination with the In3+ ion, whereas that in the other is uncoordinated but hangs in the inner sides of the channels as functionalized sites. Gas adsorption experiments demonstrate that 1 is able to selectively adsorb C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. Simultaneously, 1 shows a highly selective and sensitive fluorescence detection toward Fe3+ ion in water with good recyclability.
elements.clean_text: By employing a pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid ligand, 3-(2',5'-dicarboxylphenyl)pyridine acid (H2dcpy), a three-dimensional In3+-based metal-organic framework, H3O[In3(dcpy)4(OH)2]⋅3DMF⋅4H2O (1), with a good chemical stability toward acid and base has been synthesized. The compound 1 shows an uncommon (3,8)-connected tfz-d; UO3 topological net based on linear In3(COO)4(OH)2 clusters and also contains one-dimensional open channels. Particularly, 1 contains two types of dcpy2- linkers, in which the pyridyl group in one participates in coordination with the In3+ ion, whereas that in the other is uncoordinated but hangs in the inner sides of the channels as functionalized sites. Gas adsorption experiments demonstrate that 1 is able to selectively adsorb C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. Simultaneously, 1 shows a highly selective and sensitive fluorescence detection toward Fe3+ ion in water with good recyclability.

elements.content: A stable In−metal−organic framework with functionalized sites has been synthesized, directed by hard−soft acid−base coordination theory, which possesses an outstanding selective sensing of Fe3+ in water solution and a highly selective adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4.
elements.clean_text: A stable In-metal-organic framework with functionalized sites has been synthesized, directed by hard-soft acid-base coordination theory, which possesses an outstanding selective sensing of Fe3+ in water solution and a highly selective adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with the unique advantages of structural tenability and large surface area have recently emerged as exciting and promising porous materials, the especial performances of which addressed the solution for energy and environmental problems. With the development of material science, thermal and chemical stability has been recognized as an important obstacle for the practical applications of MOFs. It is believed that the low coordinated bond energy leads to the instability of MOFs on account of the hard–soft acid–base (HSAB) theory. Thus, the high valence states of hard acid metal ions including Fe3+, In3+, and Zr4+ ions have been used to construct robust MOFs which exhibit a high chemical stability toward acid, base, and water. The good stability makes them promising candidates in potential applications as materials in selective absorption, fluorescence, and Lewis acid catalysis. In these known MOFs containing a high valence of metal ions, the In­(III)-based MOFs with versatile topologies and functions are interesting and important, which were mainly assembled through multicarboxylate ligands, owing to the oxyphilic coordination of In3+ ions. In contrast, the N-containing units are difficult to be coordinated to the In3+ ions. Notably, from the known In–MOFs, it can be found that the generation of a cluster is crucial to the formation of In–MOFs. A variety of In3+ clusters were observed; there generally exist three kinds of In3+ clusters in MOFs, including (i) a single indium ion formulated as [In­(CO2)4], (ii) a rod-shaped [In–O–In] chain formed through the μ2-OH sharing vertex, and (iii) an oxo-bridged trimer formulated as [In3O­(O2CR)6] interlinked by three InO6 octahedra and one central μ3-oxo anion. However, more MOFs based on In3+ clusters are required to develop the coordination chemistry of In3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with the unique advantages of structural tenability and large surface area have recently emerged as exciting and promising porous materials, the especial performances of which addressed the solution for energy and environmental problems. With the development of material science, thermal and chemical stability has been recognized as an important obstacle for the practical applications of MOFs. It is believed that the low coordinated bond energy leads to the instability of MOFs on account of the hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory. Thus, the high valence states of hard acid metal ions including Fe3+, In3+, and Zr4+ ions have been used to construct robust MOFs which exhibit a high chemical stability toward acid, base, and water. The good stability makes them promising candidates in potential applications as materials in selective absorption, fluorescence, and Lewis acid catalysis. In these known MOFs containing a high valence of metal ions, the In(III)-based MOFs with versatile topologies and functions are interesting and important, which were mainly assembled through multicarboxylate ligands, owing to the oxyphilic coordination of In3+ ions. In contrast, the N-containing units are difficult to be coordinated to the In3+ ions. Notably, from the known In-MOFs, it can be found that the generation of a cluster is crucial to the formation of In-MOFs. A variety of In3+ clusters were observed; there generally exist three kinds of In3+ clusters in MOFs, including (i) a single indium ion formulated as [In(CO2)4], (ii) a rod-shaped [In-O-In] chain formed through the μ2-OH sharing vertex, and (iii) an oxo-bridged trimer formulated as [In3O(O2CR)6] interlinked by three InO6 octahedra and one central μ3-oxo anion. However, more MOFs based on In3+ clusters are required to develop the coordination chemistry of In3+ ions.

elements.content: On the other hand, recognition of metal ions is drawing intensive attention in chemistry and biological domain because metal ions are vitally important in the life system and environment. Iron is one of the essential trace elements in human body; an excess or a deficiency of this element can result in severe system disorders, such as cirrhosis, anemia, and agrypnia. Additionally, a high concentration of Fe3+ ions (0.1–0.3 mg/L) in water can cause iron pollution. At present, although numerous MOF sensors were reported, the main working mediums were focused on dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylacetamide, ethanol, or other organic solvents, limiting their practical application. Therefore, the construction of stable MOFs with Fe3+ ion sensing in water system is meaningful.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, recognition of metal ions is drawing intensive attention in chemistry and biological domain because metal ions are vitally important in the life system and environment. Iron is one of the essential trace elements in human body; an excess or a deficiency of this element can result in severe system disorders, such as cirrhosis, anemia, and agrypnia. Additionally, a high concentration of Fe3+ ions (0.1-0.3 mg/L) in water can cause iron pollution. At present, although numerous MOF sensors were reported, the main working mediums were focused on dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylacetamide, ethanol, or other organic solvents, limiting their practical application. Therefore, the construction of stable MOFs with Fe3+ ion sensing in water system is meaningful.

elements.content: Herein, an unsymmetrical pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid, 3-(2′,5′-dicarboxylphenyl)­pyridine acid (H2dcpy), is employed to synthesize In–MOFs, considering the following points: (1) the hard acid In3+ ion tends to coordinate with the hard base O donor rather than the soft base N donor, which would form a stable MOF; (2) the potential uncoordinated pyridyl N atoms as functional sites could recognize Lewis acidic metal ions. In this work, a novel three-dimensional (3D) In–MOF with one-dimensional (1D) open channels was successfully fabricated. This material reveals not only exceptional stability in water solution with the pH range from 1 to 13 but also can selectively detect Fe3+ ions in aqueous solutions. In addition, 1 shows remarkable adsorption selectivity for C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 relative to CH4.
elements.clean_text: Herein, an unsymmetrical pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid, 3-(2',5'-dicarboxylphenyl)pyridine acid (H2dcpy), is employed to synthesize In-MOFs, considering the following points: (1) the hard acid In3+ ion tends to coordinate with the hard base O donor rather than the soft base N donor, which would form a stable MOF; (2) the potential uncoordinated pyridyl N atoms as functional sites could recognize Lewis acidic metal ions. In this work, a novel three-dimensional (3D) In-MOF with one-dimensional (1D) open channels was successfully fabricated. This material reveals not only exceptional stability in water solution with the pH range from 1 to 13 but also can selectively detect Fe3+ ions in aqueous solutions. In addition, 1 shows remarkable adsorption selectivity for C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 relative to CH4.

elements.content: All the materials used in the experiments were bought commercially. The infrared (IR) spectra data were collected in the region of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer. The contents of C, H, and O in the materials were analyzed by a PerkinElmer 2400C Elemental Analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a Netzsch TG 209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and variable-temperature PXRD patterns were respectively acquired on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer and a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer. The photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrometer. An IRIS Advantage spectrometer was used to perform inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses. The gas adsorption properties were studied on an ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the materials used in the experiments were bought commercially. The infrared (IR) spectra data were collected in the region of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer. The contents of C, H, and O in the materials were analyzed by a PerkinElmer 2400C Elemental Analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a Netzsch TG 209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and variable-temperature PXRD patterns were respectively acquired on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer and a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer. The photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrometer. An IRIS Advantage spectrometer was used to perform inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses. The gas adsorption properties were studied on an ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of H2dcpy (4.7 mg, 0.02 mmol) and In­(NO3)3·5H2O (6.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL screw-cap vial containing the mixed DMF (2.0 mL) and CH3CN (1.0 mL) solvents; to this, 0.1 mL of HNO3 (2.7 M in DMF) was added and capped tightly. The mixture was heated to 100 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature and filtrating, colorless rodlike crystals were collected and dried in air (yield of 85% based on H2dcpy). Anal. Calcd for C61H34N7O26In3: C, 45.08%; N, 6.03%; H, 2.11%. Found C, 45.33%; N, 5.86%; H, 2.02%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3399 (w), 3052 (w), 2927 (w), 1664 (s), 1585 (s), 1496 (s), 1407 (s), 1373 (s), 1270 (w), 1191 (w), 1089 (s), 921 (w), 890 (w), 827 (s), 771 (m), 707 (m), 661 (w), 565 (m), 511 (m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H3O[In3(dcpy)4(OH)2]⋅3DMF⋅4H2O (1)

A mixture of H2dcpy (4.7 mg, 0.02 mmol) and In(NO3)3⋅5H2O (6.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL screw-cap vial containing the mixed DMF (2.0 mL) and CH3CN (1.0 mL) solvents; to this, 0.1 mL of HNO3 (2.7 M in DMF) was added and capped tightly. The mixture was heated to 100 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature and filtrating, colorless rodlike crystals were collected and dried in air (yield of 85% based on H2dcpy). Anal. Calcd for C61H34N7O26In3: C, 45.08%; N, 6.03%; H, 2.11%. Found C, 45.33%; N, 5.86%; H, 2.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3399 (w), 3052 (w), 2927 (w), 1664 (s), 1585 (s), 1496 (s), 1407 (s), 1373 (s), 1270 (w), 1191 (w), 1089 (s), 921 (w), 890 (w), 827 (s), 771 (m), 707 (m), 661 (w), 565 (m), 511 (m).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected by a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer at room temperature through Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The initial structure was solved by direct methods, and all the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the SHELXL-2014 program package. All the hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. The SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to eliminate the diffraction contribution of the disordered guest molecules. The detailed structural refinement results are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are provided in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected by a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer at room temperature through Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The initial structure was solved by direct methods, and all the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the SHELXL-2014 program package. All the hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. The SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to eliminate the diffraction contribution of the disordered guest molecules. The detailed structural refinement results are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are provided in Table S1.

Crystallographic Data and Structural Refinements for <bold>1</bold> complex 1 molecular formula C52H30In3N4O18 formula weight 1343.26 temperature 296(2) crystal system monoclinic space group P21/c a (Å) 11.4645(9) b (Å) 23.1952(14) c (Å) 13.0426(8) α (deg) 90 β (deg) 108.127(8) γ (deg) 90 V (Å3) 3296.2(4) Z 2 D calc (g cm–3) 1.353 F(000) 1322 R int 0.0498 reflns collected/unique 13 395/5847 GOF on F 2 1.016 R 1, wR 2 [I > 2σ(I)] 0.0583, 0.1384 R 1, wR 2 (all data) 0.0745, 0.1489

R 1 = ∑|F o| – |F c|/∑|F o|.

wR 2 = [∑w­(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑w­(F o 2)2]1/2.

The grounded sample (3 mg) of 1 was respectively immersed in 0.01 mol/L of various M­(NO3) x (M = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, and Fe3+) aqueous solutions (5 mL) for 6 h at room temperature. Then, the mixed solution was continuously ultrasonicated for 40 min to generate a homogeneous MOF suspension. Subsequently, the fluorescence spectrum of the MOF suspension was recorded. For selective experiment, 3 mg of the grounded sample of 1 was submerged into six kinds of aqueous solutions containing Fe3+ ions and other mixed metal ions (5 mL, 0.01 mol/L of Na+/Mg2+, Mg2+/Ca2+, Zn2+/Cd2+, Co2+/Pb2+, Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+, and Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+) for 6 h. Also, we use an identical method to treat the mixed solutions before the fluorescence test. For the detection of Fe3+ ions, 3 mg of the grounded sample of 1 was respectively submerged into aqueous solutions (5 mL) with various concentrations of Fe3+ ions for 6 h; then, its fluorescence intensity was measured after obtaining a uniform MOF suspension.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

The grounded sample (3 mg) of 1 was respectively immersed in 0.01 mol/L of various M(NO3) x  (M = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, and Fe3+) aqueous solutions (5 mL) for 6 h at room temperature. Then, the mixed solution was continuously ultrasonicated for 40 min to generate a homogeneous MOF suspension. Subsequently, the fluorescence spectrum of the MOF suspension was recorded. For selective experiment, 3 mg of the grounded sample of 1 was submerged into six kinds of aqueous solutions containing Fe3+ ions and other mixed metal ions (5 mL, 0.01 mol/L of Na+/Mg2+, Mg2+/Ca2+, Zn2+/Cd2+, Co2+/Pb2+, Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+, and Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+) for 6 h. Also, we use an identical method to treat the mixed solutions before the fluorescence test. For the detection of Fe3+ ions, 3 mg of the grounded sample of 1 was respectively submerged into aqueous solutions (5 mL) with various concentrations of Fe3+ ions for 6 h; then, its fluorescence intensity was measured after obtaining a uniform MOF suspension.

elements.content: The compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group P21/c, and its asymmetric unit is assembled from two In3+ ions with similar octahedral geometries, two different dcpy2–, and one OH– anionic ligand (). In1 is coordinated by one N atom and four O atoms from five dcpy2– ligands and one O atom from one μ2-OH– anion. In2 is coordinated with four carboxylate O atoms from four dcpy2– ligands and two μ2-OH– anions. Two In1 and one In2 are connected by four carboxylates and two μ2-OH– anions to give a trinuclear In3(COO)4(OH)2 linear cluster, in which the positions at both ends are occupied by the pyridyl N atoms of the other dcpy2– ligands (b). As shown in a, in the two independent dcpy2– ligands, the carboxylate groups exhibit the same connecting fashion of η0:η1-μ1 and η1:η1-μ2; however, the pyridyl groups are coordinated and uncoordinated, respectively. Therefore, the dcpy2– ligands behave as 2-connected linear and 3-connected T-shape linkers between the neighboring clusters in 1. Consequently, each cluster is bridged by four 2-connected dcpy2– and six 3-connected dcpy2– linkers to form a 3D framework. Viewed from the c-axis, in the framework exists 1D channels with a cross section of ca. 11.3 Å × 11.5 Å (the distances of C2···C2 and C18···C18, respectively, in the opposite positions in the channels, including the van der Waals radii of the atoms) and an effective void of 33.5%, in which the free pyridyl N atoms hang in the inner side as potential functionalized sites (c). Topologically, one cluster in 1 is extended by six 3-connected dcpy2– to form a (3,6)-connected kgd layer possessing (43)2(466683) topology (Figure S1). Furthermore, the cluster is connected by two pairs of 2-connected dcpy2– to form a final (3,8)-connected tfz-d; UO3 net with {(43)2(4661884)} topology (), which is very rarely obtained in the known MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

The compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group P21/c, and its asymmetric unit is assembled from two In3+ ions with similar octahedral geometries, two different dcpy2-, and one OH- anionic ligand (). In1 is coordinated by one N atom and four O atoms from five dcpy2- ligands and one O atom from one μ2-OH- anion. In2 is coordinated with four carboxylate O atoms from four dcpy2- ligands and two μ2-OH- anions. Two In1 and one In2 are connected by four carboxylates and two μ2-OH- anions to give a trinuclear In3(COO)4(OH)2 linear cluster, in which the positions at both ends are occupied by the pyridyl N atoms of the other dcpy2- ligands (b). As shown in a, in the two independent dcpy2- ligands, the carboxylate groups exhibit the same connecting fashion of η0:η1-μ1 and η1:η1-μ2; however, the pyridyl groups are coordinated and uncoordinated, respectively. Therefore, the dcpy2- ligands behave as 2-connected linear and 3-connected T-shape linkers between the neighboring clusters in 1. Consequently, each cluster is bridged by four 2-connected dcpy2- and six 3-connected dcpy2- linkers to form a 3D framework. Viewed from the c-axis, in the framework exists 1D channels with a cross section of ca. 11.3 Å × 11.5 Å (the distances of C2⋅⋅⋅C2 and C18⋅⋅⋅C18, respectively, in the opposite positions in the channels, including the van der Waals radii of the atoms) and an effective void of 33.5%, in which the free pyridyl N atoms hang in the inner side as potential functionalized sites (c). Topologically, one cluster in 1 is extended by six 3-connected dcpy2- to form a (3,6)-connected kgd layer possessing (43)2(466683) topology (Figure S1). Furthermore, the cluster is connected by two pairs of 2-connected dcpy2- to form a final (3,8)-connected tfz-d; UO3 net with {(43)2(4661884)} topology (), which is very rarely obtained in the known MOFs.

elements.content: The measured PXRD result is consistent with the simulated pattern based on the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of 1 (Figure S2). According to the TGA curve (Figure S3), a weight loss of 5.3% in the first stage from 24 to 100 °C corresponds to the removal of guest H2O molecules (calcd 5.5%) in 1. The second stage (found 13.6%) from 100 to 260 °C corresponds to the escape of guest DMF molecules (calcd 13.5%). The framework displays a high thermal stability until about 350 °C. Further, the variable-temperature PXRD patterns confirm the thermal stability of the framework below 330 °C (Figure S4). The chemical stability was estimated through soaking 1 in different aqueous solutions in a 0–14 pH range; after 12 h, the collected samples were characterized by PXRD. There is no distinct phase transition after the treatment in the solutions with pH = 1–13 (). These results show that 1 possesses good stability in thermodynamics and acidic/basic environments.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Stability

The measured PXRD result is consistent with the simulated pattern based on the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of 1 (Figure S2). According to the TGA curve (Figure S3), a weight loss of 5.3% in the first stage from 24 to 100 °C corresponds to the removal of guest H2O molecules (calcd 5.5%) in 1. The second stage (found 13.6%) from 100 to 260 °C corresponds to the escape of guest DMF molecules (calcd 13.5%). The framework displays a high thermal stability until about 350 °C. Further, the variable-temperature PXRD patterns confirm the thermal stability of the framework below 330 °C (Figure S4). The chemical stability was estimated through soaking 1 in different aqueous solutions in a 0-14 pH range; after 12 h, the collected samples were characterized by PXRD. There is no distinct phase transition after the treatment in the solutions with pH = 1-13 (). These results show that 1 possesses good stability in thermodynamics and acidic/basic environments.

elements.content: PXRD profiles of 1 after being soaked in water, acidic, and basic solutions.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD profiles of 1 after being soaked in water, acidic, and basic solutions.

elements.content: The fluorescent property of 1 in solid state was tested at room temperature. As shown in Figure S5, the strong emission peak of 1 exists at 470 nm, whereas the excitation peak emerges at 356 nm. The intense fluorescence, good stability, as well as the existence of functionalized pyridyl sites in the channels of 1 allow us to evaluate it as a fluorescent probe to recognize metal ions in water. The powder sample of 1 was immersed in 0.01 mol/L of various M­(NO3) n aqueous solutions including Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, and Fe3+, respectively. The mixtures were sonicated before fluorescence measurements. Compared with the original spectra, the metal ions cause different changes in the fluorescence intensity of 1. As shown in a, the fluorescence intensity of 1 remained steady for Mg2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Na+, and K+ ions; Co2+ and Ca2+ ions cause a slight increase; Cu2+, Pb2+, and Cr3+ ions produce moderate quenching; whereas Fe3+ ions manifest quenching with an efficiency of as much as 96% in contrast to that of itself. A persuasive reason for this selective quenching is that when Fe3+ ions spread through the channels of 1, interactions between Fe3+ and free pyridyl N atoms occurred.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The fluorescent property of 1 in solid state was tested at room temperature. As shown in Figure S5, the strong emission peak of 1 exists at 470 nm, whereas the excitation peak emerges at 356 nm. The intense fluorescence, good stability, as well as the existence of functionalized pyridyl sites in the channels of 1 allow us to evaluate it as a fluorescent probe to recognize metal ions in water. The powder sample of 1 was immersed in 0.01 mol/L of various M(NO3) n  aqueous solutions including Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, and Fe3+, respectively. The mixtures were sonicated before fluorescence measurements. Compared with the original spectra, the metal ions cause different changes in the fluorescence intensity of 1. As shown in a, the fluorescence intensity of 1 remained steady for Mg2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Na+, and K+ ions; Co2+ and Ca2+ ions cause a slight increase; Cu2+, Pb2+, and Cr3+ ions produce moderate quenching; whereas Fe3+ ions manifest quenching with an efficiency of as much as 96% in contrast to that of itself. A persuasive reason for this selective quenching is that when Fe3+ ions spread through the channels of 1, interactions between Fe3+ and free pyridyl N atoms occurred.

elements.content: (a) Luminescent intensity at 356 nm of 1 treated with 0.01 M of various different metal ions in water. (b) Luminescence intensity at 356 nm of 1 dispersed in water with the addition of different mixed ions (0.01 M) (1: Na+/Mg2+; 2: Mg2+/Ca2+; 3: Zn2+/Cd2+; 4: Co2+/Pb2+; 5: Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+; 6: Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+) and Fe3+-incorporated systems (0.01 M). (c) Luminescence spectra of 1 in aqueous solutions with Fe­(NO3)3 at different concentrations. (d) Plot of relative luminescence intensity vs Fe3+ concentration.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Luminescent intensity at 356 nm of 1 treated with 0.01 M of various different metal ions in water. (b) Luminescence intensity at 356 nm of 1 dispersed in water with the addition of different mixed ions (0.01 M) (1: Na+/Mg2+; 2: Mg2+/Ca2+; 3: Zn2+/Cd2+; 4: Co2+/Pb2+; 5: Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+; 6: Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+) and Fe3+-incorporated systems (0.01 M). (c) Luminescence spectra of 1 in aqueous solutions with Fe(NO3)3 at different concentrations. (d) Plot of relative luminescence intensity vs Fe3+ concentration.

elements.content: Owing to the coexistence of versatile metal ions in real solution system, a high selectivity for metal ions is imperative. Therefore, the sample of 1 was submerged into six kinds of aqueous solutions containing Fe3+ ions and other mixed metal ions (0.01 mol/L of Na+/Mg2+, Mg2+/Ca2+, Zn2+/Cd2+, Co2+/Pb2+, Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+, and Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+). As shown in b, the mixed ions do not have an obvious impact on the fluorescence intensity of 1. Conversely, when the Fe3+ ions were respectively added to the above solutions with mixed metal ions, the fluorescence intensity of 1 showed a significant decline. Therefore, 1 can specifically sense Fe3+ ions unaffected by other metal ions.
elements.clean_text: Owing to the coexistence of versatile metal ions in real solution system, a high selectivity for metal ions is imperative. Therefore, the sample of 1 was submerged into six kinds of aqueous solutions containing Fe3+ ions and other mixed metal ions (0.01 mol/L of Na+/Mg2+, Mg2+/Ca2+, Zn2+/Cd2+, Co2+/Pb2+, Zn2+/Cu2+/Co2+, and Zn2+/Cd2+/Cr3+). As shown in b, the mixed ions do not have an obvious impact on the fluorescence intensity of 1. Conversely, when the Fe3+ ions were respectively added to the above solutions with mixed metal ions, the fluorescence intensity of 1 showed a significant decline. Therefore, 1 can specifically sense Fe3+ ions unaffected by other metal ions.

elements.content: In addition, a series of inquiry experiments were carried out in aqueous solutions with various concentrations of Fe3+. The fluorescence intensity of 1 is almost entirely quenched at an Fe3+ ion concentration of 10–3 M, and it still can recognize Fe3+ even at a concentration of as low as 10–6 M (c). The correlation between I 0/I and Fe3+ ion concentration was evaluated through the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation. As presented in d, this correlation can be well-fitted by I 0/I = 5.196 × exp­([Fe3+]/5.731) – 4.714, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of 1 in pure water and water solutions containing different concentrations of Fe3+ ions, respectively. In addition, the deviation appeared at a high concentration, indicating a coexisting dynamic and static quenching process. For 1, the quenching constant K SV calculated from the S–V plot at low concentrations is 4.3 × 103 M–1 (Figure S6), which is comparable with those probes with outstanding Fe3+ sensing properties (Table S2).
elements.clean_text: In addition, a series of inquiry experiments were carried out in aqueous solutions with various concentrations of Fe3+. The fluorescence intensity of 1 is almost entirely quenched at an Fe3+ ion concentration of 10-3 M, and it still can recognize Fe3+ even at a concentration of as low as 10-6 M (c). The correlation between I 0/I and Fe3+ ion concentration was evaluated through the Stern-Volmer (S-V) equation. As presented in d, this correlation can be well-fitted by I 0/I = 5.196 × exp([Fe3+]/5.731) - 4.714, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of 1 in pure water and water solutions containing different concentrations of Fe3+ ions, respectively. In addition, the deviation appeared at a high concentration, indicating a coexisting dynamic and static quenching process. For 1, the quenching constant K SV calculated from the S-V plot at low concentrations is 4.3 × 103 M-1 (Figure S6), which is comparable with those probes with outstanding Fe3+ sensing properties (Table S2).

elements.content: Furthermore, after 1 was washed with acetone several times, its fluorescence intensity was well-retained after five runs (a). Meanwhile, the PXRD patterns proved that the crystallinity and structural integrity of 1 exhibited no change after the detection test (b), suggesting excellent recyclability. The high selectivity and sensitivity and good recyclability for Fe3+ ions, together with the stability in acidic/basic aqueous solutions, make 1 competitive relative to other MOF fluorescent probes.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, after 1 was washed with acetone several times, its fluorescence intensity was well-retained after five runs (a). Meanwhile, the PXRD patterns proved that the crystallinity and structural integrity of 1 exhibited no change after the detection test (b), suggesting excellent recyclability. The high selectivity and sensitivity and good recyclability for Fe3+ ions, together with the stability in acidic/basic aqueous solutions, make 1 competitive relative to other MOF fluorescent probes.

(The blue columns represent the initial fluorescence intensity, and the yellow columns represent the intensity upon the addition of an aqueous solution of 0.01 M Fe3+ ion.) elements.content: In a general way, the fluorescence quenching of MOFs is attributed to the following three reasons: structural damage, ion exchange, or interactions between the entered metal ions and the frameworks of MOFs. The PXRD patterns of 1 before and after the fluorescence experiments were consistent, excluding the possibility of structural damage (Figure S7). The corresponding ICP reveals that the samples of 1 after being immersed in the aqueous solutions of Fe3+ ions do not contain Fe3+, eliminating the possibility of ion exchange. Therefore, the interaction between the entered metal ions and the framework is the major reason causing the quenching behavior. This kind of fluorescence quenching is possibly connected with the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) and photoinduced electron transfer (PET), as observed in other MOFs. Because of the conjugated organic ligand, the energy absorbed gives rise to fluorescence; Fe3+ ions possess unsaturated 3d orbitals to accept electrons. On the basis of excitation, the electrons were moved to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of Fe3+ ions through a nonradiative path, leading to fluorescence quenching of MOF. Notably, the uncoordinated pyridyl N atom can also provide one lone pair of electrons to the Fe3+ ion, increasing the recognition efficiency. From the above discussion, PET is fit to illuminate the mechanism of this quenching. Meanwhile, to verify whether FRET occurs or not, UV–vis absorbance of the metal ions was explored. The absorption spectrum of Fe3+ ions is significantly overlapped with the emission of 1, whereas the overlap is negligible for other ions (Figure S8). Therefore, PET and distance-dependent FRET result in the fluorescence quenching together.
elements.clean_text: In a general way, the fluorescence quenching of MOFs is attributed to the following three reasons: structural damage, ion exchange, or interactions between the entered metal ions and the frameworks of MOFs. The PXRD patterns of 1 before and after the fluorescence experiments were consistent, excluding the possibility of structural damage (Figure S7). The corresponding ICP reveals that the samples of 1 after being immersed in the aqueous solutions of Fe3+ ions do not contain Fe3+, eliminating the possibility of ion exchange. Therefore, the interaction between the entered metal ions and the framework is the major reason causing the quenching behavior. This kind of fluorescence quenching is possibly connected with the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) and photoinduced electron transfer (PET), as observed in other MOFs. Because of the conjugated organic ligand, the energy absorbed gives rise to fluorescence; Fe3+ ions possess unsaturated 3d orbitals to accept electrons. On the basis of excitation, the electrons were moved to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of Fe3+ ions through a nonradiative path, leading to fluorescence quenching of MOF. Notably, the uncoordinated pyridyl N atom can also provide one lone pair of electrons to the Fe3+ ion, increasing the recognition efficiency. From the above discussion, PET is fit to illuminate the mechanism of this quenching. Meanwhile, to verify whether FRET occurs or not, UV-vis absorbance of the metal ions was explored. The absorption spectrum of Fe3+ ions is significantly overlapped with the emission of 1, whereas the overlap is negligible for other ions (Figure S8). Therefore, PET and distance-dependent FRET result in the fluorescence quenching together.

elements.content: Before the adsorption test, the samples were soaked in acetone for 3 days, and the exchanged sample was activated under vacuum at 120 °C for 10 h, as confirmed by TGA and PXRD (Figures S2 and S3). At 77 K, 1 adsorbs N2 of 81.0 cm3 g–1 at 1 atm (), however, not exhibiting the reversible type I sorption behavior, but instead showing a noticeable hysteresis in desorption, which could be attributed to the relatively narrow pore that prevents the gas escape. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface areas of 1 are assessed to be 290 and 345 m2 g–1, respectively. From the Dubinin–Astakhov mode, a total microporous volume of 0.126 cm3 g–1 is given, and a median pore width of 6.4 Å is provided based on the Horvath–Kawazoe mode.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Properties

Before the adsorption test, the samples were soaked in acetone for 3 days, and the exchanged sample was activated under vacuum at 120 °C for 10 h, as confirmed by TGA and PXRD (Figures S2 and S3). At 77 K, 1 adsorbs N2 of 81.0 cm3 g-1 at 1 atm (), however, not exhibiting the reversible type I sorption behavior, but instead showing a noticeable hysteresis in desorption, which could be attributed to the relatively narrow pore that prevents the gas escape. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface areas of 1 are assessed to be 290 and 345 m2 g-1, respectively. From the Dubinin-Astakhov mode, a total microporous volume of 0.126 cm3 g-1 is given, and a median pore width of 6.4 Å is provided based on the Horvath-Kawazoe mode.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherms of 1 at 77 K; P 0 represents 1 atm.
elements.clean_text: 6  N2 sorption isotherms of 1 at 77 K; P 0 represents 1 atm.

elements.content: To further study the potential applications of 1 for gas capture and separation, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2, C2H4, CO2, and CH4 were recorded at 273 and 298 K under 1 atm. As presented in , at 273 and 298 K, the C2H2 uptakes of 1 are 68 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 58 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, and the C2H4 uptakes are 51 and 45 cm3 g–1, respectively. For CO2, the adsorption amounts are 61 and 42 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. However, the CH4 adsorption amounts are very lower (22 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 14 cm3 g–1 at 298 K), indicating the preferential selective capture of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used to calculate the separation selectivity of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4 in 1 for the binary C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and CO2/CH4 mixtures at 298 K (Figure S9). It is found that, for the equimolar mixtures of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and CO2/CH4, the simulated selectivities are 18, 12, and 5, respectively, at 1 atm (a). Such selectivity values in 1 are outstanding among MOFs which possess high C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 selectivity.
elements.clean_text: To further study the potential applications of 1 for gas capture and separation, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2, C2H4, CO2, and CH4 were recorded at 273 and 298 K under 1 atm. As presented in , at 273 and 298 K, the C2H2 uptakes of 1 are 68 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 58 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, and the C2H4 uptakes are 51 and 45 cm3 g-1, respectively. For CO2, the adsorption amounts are 61 and 42 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. However, the CH4 adsorption amounts are very lower (22 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 14 cm3 g-1 at 298 K), indicating the preferential selective capture of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used to calculate the separation selectivity of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4 in 1 for the binary C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and CO2/CH4 mixtures at 298 K (Figure S9). It is found that, for the equimolar mixtures of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and CO2/CH4, the simulated selectivities are 18, 12, and 5, respectively, at 1 atm (a). Such selectivity values in 1 are outstanding among MOFs which possess high C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 selectivity.

elements.content: (a) IAST adsorption selectivities and isotherms of 1 for C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4 at 298 K. (b) C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 adsorption heat calculated according to the virial equation.
elements.clean_text: 8  (a) IAST adsorption selectivities and isotherms of 1 for C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4 at 298 K. (b) C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 adsorption heat calculated according to the virial equation.

elements.content: The good selectivity about C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 in 1 may be closely related to the high polarity of the pore environment, in which the anionic framework, uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms, and pyridine N atoms produce an electric field and then enhance the affinity of the framework with the quadrupolar C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 molecules. Furthermore, to understand the interactions between the framework and the C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 molecules, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was calculated from the virial equation on the basis of the adsorption isotherms tested at 273 and 298 K (b and S10). At near zero coverage, the calculated Q st values of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 are 30.0, 29.0, and 26.8 kJ mol–1, respectively, demonstrating the strong interactions between the framework and gas molecules, which are responsible for the significant selectivity.
elements.clean_text: The good selectivity about C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 in 1 may be closely related to the high polarity of the pore environment, in which the anionic framework, uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms, and pyridine N atoms produce an electric field and then enhance the affinity of the framework with the quadrupolar C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 molecules. Furthermore, to understand the interactions between the framework and the C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 molecules, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was calculated from the virial equation on the basis of the adsorption isotherms tested at 273 and 298 K (b and S10). At near zero coverage, the calculated Q st values of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 are 30.0, 29.0, and 26.8 kJ mol-1, respectively, demonstrating the strong interactions between the framework and gas molecules, which are responsible for the significant selectivity.

elements.content: In summary, guided by the HSAB coordination theory, a new stable In–MOF 1 with polar channels has been synthesized through a pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid linker. The existence of free pyridyl functionalized sites in the MOF leads not only to an outstanding selective recognition of Fe3+ ions in the water system but also to a highly selective adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. Compared to the most In–MOFs synthesized based on multicarboxylate ligands, this work carves out a way to the rational assembly of functional stable In–MOFs based on pyridylcarboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, guided by the HSAB coordination theory, a new stable In-MOF 1 with polar channels has been synthesized through a pyridyl-decorated dicarboxylic acid linker. The existence of free pyridyl functionalized sites in the MOF leads not only to an outstanding selective recognition of Fe3+ ions in the water system but also to a highly selective adsorption of C2H2, C2H4, and CO2 over CH4. Compared to the most In-MOFs synthesized based on multicarboxylate ligands, this work carves out a way to the rational assembly of functional stable In-MOFs based on pyridylcarboxylate ligands.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of H2dcpy (4.7 mg, 0.02 mmol) and In­(NO3)3·5H2O (6.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL screw-cap vial containing the mixed DMF (2.0 mL) and CH3CN (1.0 mL) solvents; to this, 0.1 mL of HNO3 (2.7 M in DMF) was added and capped tightly. The mixture was heated to 100 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature and filtrating, colorless rodlike crystals were collected and dried in air (yield of 85% based on H2dcpy). Anal. Calcd for C61H34N7O26In3: C, 45.08%; N, 6.03%; H, 2.11%. Found C, 45.33%; N, 5.86%; H, 2.02%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3399 (w), 3052 (w), 2927 (w), 1664 (s), 1585 (s), 1496 (s), 1407 (s), 1373 (s), 1270 (w), 1191 (w), 1089 (s), 921 (w), 890 (w), 827 (s), 771 (m), 707 (m), 661 (w), 565 (m), 511 (m).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H3O[In3(dcpy)4(OH)2]⋅3DMF⋅4H2O (1)

A mixture of H2dcpy (4.7 mg, 0.02 mmol) and In(NO3)3⋅5H2O (6.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL screw-cap vial containing the mixed DMF (2.0 mL) and CH3CN (1.0 mL) solvents; to this, 0.1 mL of HNO3 (2.7 M in DMF) was added and capped tightly. The mixture was heated to 100 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling to room temperature and filtrating, colorless rodlike crystals were collected and dried in air (yield of 85% based on H2dcpy). Anal. Calcd for C61H34N7O26In3: C, 45.08%; N, 6.03%; H, 2.11%. Found C, 45.33%; N, 5.86%; H, 2.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3399 (w), 3052 (w), 2927 (w), 1664 (s), 1585 (s), 1496 (s), 1407 (s), 1373 (s), 1270 (w), 1191 (w), 1089 (s), 921 (w), 890 (w), 827 (s), 771 (m), 707 (m), 661 (w), 565 (m), 511 (m).

cln_elements.content:
The measured PXRD result is consistent with the simulated pattern based on the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of 1 (Figure S2). According to the TGA curve (Figure S3), a weight loss of 5.3% in the first stage from 24 to 100 °C corresponds to the removal of guest H2O molecules (calcd 5.5%) in 1. The second stage (found 13.6%) from 100 to 260 °C corresponds to the escape of guest DMF molecules (calcd 13.5%). The framework displays a high thermal stability until about 350 °C. Further, the variable-temperature PXRD patterns confirm the thermal stability of the framework below 330 °C (Figure S4). The chemical stability was estimated through soaking 1 in different aqueous solutions in a 0–14 pH range; after 12 h, the collected samples were characterized by PXRD. There is no distinct phase transition after the treatment in the solutions with pH = 1–13 (). These results show that 1 possesses good stability in thermodynamics and acidic/basic environments.

Sorption Properties

Before the adsorption test, the samples were soaked in acetone for 3 days, and the exchanged sample was activated under vacuum at 120 °C for 10 h, as confirmed by TGA and PXRD (Figures S2 and S3). At 77 K, 1 adsorbs N2 of 81.0 cm3 g–1 at 1 atm (), however, not exhibiting the reversible type I sorption behavior, but instead showing a noticeable hysteresis in desorption, which could be attributed to the relatively narrow pore that prevents the gas escape. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface areas of 1 are assessed to be 290 and 345 m2 g–1, respectively. From the Dubinin–Astakhov mode, a total microporous volume of 0.126 cm3 g–1 is given, and a median pore width of 6.4 Å is provided based on the Horvath–Kawazoe mode.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Stability

The measured PXRD result is consistent with the simulated pattern based on the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of 1 (Figure S2). According to the TGA curve (Figure S3), a weight loss of 5.3% in the first stage from 24 to 100 °C corresponds to the removal of guest H2O molecules (calcd 5.5%) in 1. The second stage (found 13.6%) from 100 to 260 °C corresponds to the escape of guest DMF molecules (calcd 13.5%). The framework displays a high thermal stability until about 350 °C. Further, the variable-temperature PXRD patterns confirm the thermal stability of the framework below 330 °C (Figure S4). The chemical stability was estimated through soaking 1 in different aqueous solutions in a 0-14 pH range; after 12 h, the collected samples were characterized by PXRD. There is no distinct phase transition after the treatment in the solutions with pH = 1-13 (). These results show that 1 possesses good stability in thermodynamics and acidic/basic environments.

Sorption Properties

Before the adsorption test, the samples were soaked in acetone for 3 days, and the exchanged sample was activated under vacuum at 120 °C for 10 h, as confirmed by TGA and PXRD (Figures S2 and S3). At 77 K, 1 adsorbs N2 of 81.0 cm3 g-1 at 1 atm (), however, not exhibiting the reversible type I sorption behavior, but instead showing a noticeable hysteresis in desorption, which could be attributed to the relatively narrow pore that prevents the gas escape. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface areas of 1 are assessed to be 290 and 345 m2 g-1, respectively. From the Dubinin-Astakhov mode, a total microporous volume of 0.126 cm3 g-1 is given, and a median pore width of 6.4 Å is provided based on the Horvath-Kawazoe mode.

Stable Indium-Pyridylcarboxylate Framework: Selective
